A couple suggestions (hey, it's easy to make suggestions when I'm not the
one who actually has to program them!) ...
 
In terms of generating truly new maps ... this isn't that hard, if you first
create a bunch of pre-designed pieces that can either snap together, or just
be placed randomly on a map.  For example, say you start with a blank map of
all dirt, or all grass, etc.  Then you design pieces like:
    * forest of 12x6 (can be circular, square, or blob-ular) ...
    * small house: 6x6 square, with tile inside, and opening facing
[west/east/north/south/etc.]
    * small lake
    * large lake/ocean
    * big house -- maybe "L" shaped or something.
 
This is basically how levels for the Diablo series are constructed.  Once
you have those, you can start with the backgrounds:
    a) add from 1-5 "lake" objects
    b) add from 1-5 "forest" objects
 
... then you move to the foreground:
    c) add 1-2 "small house" objects
    d) add 1 "big house" object
 
... etc.  Obviously, the more work you put in to making sure you don't get
weird cases (a house in the middle of a lake, etc.), the better, but even a
very simple implementation can generate quite reasonable maps.
 
Also, there's a function in the scenario editor right now called the
"smoother" (Zardus can probably point anyone who's interested to the right
place).  It takes care of things like randoming grass (so that it's not all
one tile), and making walls/trees/water/etc. form into the right tiles based
on where they are in relation to other pieces.  Using that code (or similar
code), you can just draw "generic wall" in a pattern, then have the smoother
turn it into the correct wall pieces.
 
Anyway, just some thoughts!
 
--Tom
